name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: This is their setup for boiling sap: a welded together oven for burning firewood with an evaporation tank welded to the top. There are lots of ways to do this!🍁🧵 https://t.co/gcarg0spHk

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: We filter the syrup again, bring it back up to a boil inside, and then can the syrup. 🍁🧵 https://t.co/e6xYO5YAvd

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: When the sap gets closer to being finished, we measure the Brix using a hydrometer. It’s less precise than a refractometer but faster because you need to cool down the sap before you can use the former. The final phase can go quickly, so we test frequently. 🍁🧵 https://t.co/z4pNBlWYJ4

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: We then boil the concentrated sap for a long time in our “sugar shack” tent. This evaporation tank holds about 25 gallons of sap. We can monitor conditions, such as sap temp, from inside. 🍁🧵 https://t.co/R339gpr0v1

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Sugar content in maple syrup (and other things) is measured in Brix; 1 Brix means there is 1 gram sucrose/100 grams. The sap fresh off the tree is about 3 but after the RO is closer to 10. Maple syrup is be between 66-68.9 Brix. The tool to measure this is a refractometer.🍁🧵 https://t.co/qOUCuX7bWI

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Maple syrup is sap reduced to 1/40 to 1/50. To speed up the process, we use a reverse osmosis process (RO). Sap is pumped through 3 filters, which yields 25% concentrated sap and 75% pure distilled water. We get through about 5 gallons of sap an hour. 🍁🧵 https://t.co/f81ACTfKBU

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: We filter the sap twice. The first time, it’s a very clear color. 🍁🧵 https://t.co/sf4iP58Jzj

tweet: We collect the sap in the later morning and again in the evening if conditions are good. Yesterday, we collected 170 gallons of sap. 🍁🧵 https://t.co/kKOhXF8cpB

tweet: Being pro-abortion doesn't mean I think people should have abortions or be forced to have abortions. It means I recognize abortion care is health care. I'm pro-abortion in the way I'm pro- other medical procedures. Doctors, not legislators, should regulate abortion procedures.

tweet: @jdcollens Not sure why retreat is the wrong word - it means withdrawing or stepping back. At retreats, I don’t do student emails, time consuming service, etc - I am withdrawing from everything to focus on writing with a clear head and fresh perspective.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @jdcollens You may have also noticed that writing retreats are popular among affinity groups, ie women, POC. Retreats are a place for togetherness and belonging, place to vent, brainstorm and problem solve. For isolated academics in white male departments - these gatherings are everything.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @jdcollens Counterpoint: I feel energized after a writing retreat - more motivated, fresh perspective. It can be hard for me to find dedicated research time - so I think of writing retreats as work, not vacation getting intruded upon.

tweet: I should add - this pattern generally holds for Republicans (men and women): Republicans tended to prefer the later gestational ban over the earlier one, especially when the bill sponsor was a woman.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: We compared support for 6 wk gestational bans to 10 wk in an experiment, varying if there was additional framing “to protect women’s health” & gender of bill sponsor. Framing didn’t matter a lot but way more people support 10 wk bans than 6 week, especially with a woman sponsor.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: We are so passionate about this project. I'm immensely grateful we have received funding to continue this work. Thank you thank you thank you to everyone who encouraged us along the way. We look forward to sharing more of our findings with the world!

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: For those of you who have received several NSF rejections: keep trying! We almost gave up on applying again for this project (it's so much work to apply!) – but I’m so glad we didn’t. We've learned a lot through this process, including the importance of being resilient & scrappy.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Candis & I have the privilege of working w/ @KellenAKane & @TraceeMSaunders. They have been amazing collaborators and this NSF grant will help support their work on this. We work with several undergrads & this grant will allow us to provide research opportunities for even more.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: The NSF project will allow us to build on this early work. Our mixed-methods book project “Unplanning Parenthood” will provide an overview of Title X, map contraception deserts in all 50 states+DC, discuss the politics of policy implementation and the war on repro healthcare.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: We have a forthcoming @PoliticsGenderJ article about Planned Parenthood & the implementation of Title X. Republicans around the country have advocated for “defunding Planned Parenthood.” We show the absence of PP widens contraception deserts, leaving far more people w/o access.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Our first peer reviewed publication, at @JHPPL, measures contraception deserts. We find that poor people & POC are more likely to live in an area with less access to affordable family planning. https://t.co/IXwCAwTr7u

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Our work focuses on the intersection of federalism, politics, health & geography. We first introduced the concept of contraception deserts in a 2016 @monkeycageblog post. https://t.co/NqaHX9bfc0 We later wrote a @GenderPolicyRpt with some early findings. https://t.co/oXwNI1Ur2x

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: When @ProfCandis & I were in our first years as assistant professors @UNC @UNCPublicPolicy, we made it a goal to get an NSF grant to support our work on reproductive healthcare access. We applied to NSF 4 times btwn 2017-2021. I am so excited to share the 4th time was the charm.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: I don’t begrudge Mrs. Dempster and others for not recognizing my autism. However, the cruel way she belittled me for not doing my homework was so disproportionate to what I had done wrong. (Not done my homework, again, definitely a pattern.)

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: There is still a gender gap in the diagnosis of autism today. Many (most?) people still believe it’s bc of differences in prevalence. It’s actually bc people have gendered stereotypes about autism & autistic girls are better at and do more “masking.” https://t.co/TrI12rodbR

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Side note: Aspergers Syndrome, once a separate diagnosis, is part of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). I, and many others, strongly prefer to not use that outdated term, in no small part bc Dr. Asperger sent disabled kids to a Nazi “clinic” to be used in experiments.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: During my 4th grade year, “Asperger’s” was added to the DSM-4. Bc I have high intelligence (no need for special ed interventions) & was a girl, I did not fit the mold of what an autistic person “looked” like.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: I internalized what she said. That was 4th grade & I spent the next four years in a cycle of being identified as “gifted” & failing classes. I got kicked out of honors math. (Homework issue, again.)

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: One of my autistic quirks is I have extremely good recall for conversations and, depending on the context, can sometimes recall them word-for-word. I remember that conversation like it was five minutes ago.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: I was a smart kid who never, ever misbehaved but got bad grades all thru 8th grade bc I thought homework was easy & a waste of time. I wasn’t the “bad student” she & others perceived me as. I was & am autistic. No one understood me then. It was rough. (It still is, sometimes.)

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @prof_mirya Diagnostic tests & examples used by doctors are gendered, i.e., "Does your child hyper focus on things, like the wheels on a toy truck?" The behavioral signs of autism are seen as "wrong" for boys but "normal" for girls (shyness, emotional, etc). Hence huge gender diagnosis gap.

tweet: This bill isn't likely to pass, in fact, NC is also considering expanding LGBTQ protections. But that isn't the point. Research demonstrates mental health of trans youth suffers when political discussions target them and question their humanity. (Or maybe that was the point.)

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: This bill would also prevent trans youth & young adults from receiving gender-affirming health care. There are true experts in this field w/ standards of care. They should be making decisions about treatment, not legislators. I say the same about abortion. https://t.co/YAIDD9vU91

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: The people directly targeted by this bill are trans youth & young adults. Trans youth have high rates of depression & suicide rates, harassment in schools, homelessness due to family rejection. There is a LOT of evidence of the struggle trans youth face. https://t.co/AUiBew2Knf

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: That means anyone who is attracted to people of the same sex is not conforming. High school teachers who suspect a student is gay are supposed to tell that students' parents - even if they don't KNOW they are gay. We would need to report simply "signs" of gender nonconformity.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Gender nonconformity can also be anyone who is LGBTQ, basically. To "conform" with gender, one "should" marry someone of the opposite sex. The Supreme Court recently recognized this dynamic in a decision recently written by Justice Gorsuch. https://t.co/nE3JjzdBcK

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: So, would this bill require educators to tell parents (in writing) if their high school daughter wants to take shop class? Or if a 4th grade tomboy wants to play with the boys on the playground? Am I supposed to notify parents of college students if their daughter has short hair?

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: To get to the question of gender nonconformity, we have to start with gender norms. Girls/women "should" be feminine, in to "domestic arts," nurturing, & docile. Boys/men "should" be masculine, assertive, a leader, sports, etc. Nonconformity happens when girls "do" boy things.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: I want to recognize that I'm in a place of immense privilege here. This was my first job, R1 university on the TT, and have found a network of support. So many of our amazing colleagues are in more precarious employment contracts and don't have supportive workplace environments.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: I'm excited about the research that I do and the classes I teach. I'm also REALLY excited to play my role in this network of supporting women and other under-represented scholars. I've been pretty outspoken as an untenured professor but I'm eager to be even more outspoken. 😉

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @PolisciMonica I am now realizing just HOW much energy and effort I have gone to to blend in my entire life. It’s no wonder I am exhausted, anxious and depressed!

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @PolisciMonica One of the things is clothes. I have been so physically uncomfortable my entire life in clothes. I’ve known I have sensory and texture issues (I self stim a lot) but I’ve never not worn what society “tells” me I should. It’s amazing what a difference just that feels like.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: In some ways the pandemic has felt liberating to me because it’s made me realize how much I mask and it’s allowed me the opportunity to just ... not. I’m going to try to keep masking less post pandemic.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @jlazarus001 I make the connection between politics and policy very explicit in my lectures. I often talk about how politics frequently results in sub optimal policy, and that politics significantly constrain feasible policy alternatives.  It helps them when they do assignments like this.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: I’ve been told “you don’t seem autistic to me” so many times by people who think it’s a compliment (it’s not) or doubt my diagnosis. Autistic women are very likely to mask or camouflage to blend in, resulting in later or no diagnosis. (It’s exhausting.) https://t.co/dXa0bEbquJ https://t.co/P4eINCKGQl

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @tkinias @ssiddiqui83 Yes, exactly! The common thread for us is that we are interested in "traditional" questions for our disciplines but we are ALSO interested in the applied real world implications than our home disciplines would normally be.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: @tkinias @ssiddiqui83 It really is a "big tent" discipline. I see you are are a historian. We have two historians on faculty, for instance. I might refer to them as historians, professors of policy history, policy scholars, etc. It probably depends on the context and is fluid.

tweet: @tkinias @ssiddiqui83 Yeah, that is also totally a normal way to refer to someone. We tend to have duel identities. I am probably referred to as a policy scholar more than a political scientist in the media.

tweet: @DrAbrahm @amydiehl What research exists shows very intersectional effects. Black men do worse, as do Asians or people with accents. Professors are also penalized for failing to conform to intersectional stereotypes, ie Latina women very punished for not being “warm” enough.

tweet: @DrAbrahm @amydiehl We do talk about race in the paper. Unfortunately, because white people are over represented in academia, it’s been harder to study POC. The sample sizes are often just too (shamefully) small.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Twitter folks know I’ve been on the “SETs are problematic” beat for a while now. Check out (& please share!) this new pub with @jenniesweetcush. We’ve been hyping this project forever. Now you can see it! It's a long thread but this is an important and complex issue. https://t.co/TcVlLVMaGE

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: I’m happy to answer any questions you all have about this research. (RIP my mentions 😅) Apologies for any typos or lack of clarity above. This is the longest thread I've written!

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: I’ve published a fair amount of research as an AP but this pub is the one that I'm most eager to share with the world. The stakes here are so high - SETs are ubiquitous – but there are actual real steps we can make to make them less bad.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: 6) We need more research on interventions to reduce bias. What little research exists yields some promising leads. Reducing size of scale can mitigate bias, RCTs that make students aware of biases may mitigate gender gap – but the evidence here is contradictory.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: 5) Admin should not rely on SETs as sole method of assessing teaching. It’s true that other forms of assessment also prone to bias, ie classroom observations. But these assessments aren’t systematically biased in same way. Better to use multiple imperfect tools than just one.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: I know personally how negative comments burn and linger, for years. They can make you more insecure and nervous about teaching. Particularly nasty comments can cause genuine mental anguish.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Comments are hard to aggregate, small sample, frequently have contradictory feedback (validity issue). Further, even careful reading of comments is prone to novelty bias (likely to remember uncommon findings) and negativity bias (more influenced by negative information than pos).

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: 4) Restrict or eliminate use of qualitative comments. Across all studies, clearest example of equity bias is in comment section. These can be brutal and extremely disempowering for faculty who get sexist, racist, homophobic comments.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Report ratings from multiple questions, not a single global question about overall teaching, to reduce the effect of measurement error.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Unfortunately, reporting means seems to be most common now. But this is a relatively easy thing to change! The reasoning of using median or modal values rather than mean seems to resonate with many people. It’s a pretty basic statistical argument here.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Most faculty get mostly positive reviews, which don’t follow a normal distribution (they have a negative skew). Mean of skewed distribution more influenced by outliers. Admin should look at overall distribution, look at median or modal responses, not means.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: 3) Interpret results with caution. Ideally, evals should compare faculty member’s trajectory over time, ideally, within a course. Bc equity bias manifests through lower evals for astereotypic instructors, comparisons across faculty further disadvantage marginalized faculty.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: An aside: There is a lot of online chatter about whether telling students about biases in particular mitigates bias or inflames a backlash. Some experimental evidence suggests mitigation but others don’t. Many faculty have anecdotal evidence of backlash. We need more research.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: 2) Increase validity of SETs by increasing response rate. Small samples likely to be unrepresentative. Tips to improve RR: give time to complete in class (faculty shld leave room), explain how SETs are used by admin (most students don’t know this!), how faculty use SET feedback.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: 1) Contextualize evals as perceptions of student learning - not a measure of actual teaching. When properly contextualized as feedback on experience (NOT teaching), they can provide some useful feedback for faculty and administrators about students' satisfaction with the course.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Most universities/colleges are unlikely to eliminate use of SETs anytime soon, in part bc of inertia & in part bc there aren’t clear alternatives to SETs that don't also fall prone to measurement or equity bias. Here are some practical rec's on how to use SETs in a less bad way.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: We go in to detail about evidence for equity bias. Bc this is the bulk of the online discussion of SETs, I want to share with twitter some of the nuance. Equity bias is more prominent in some disciplines; students evaluate profs through a gender lens, evidence of affinity effect. https://t.co/G7LWY5iGXV

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Equity bias occurs when variables outside instructor’s control influence SETs: instructor’s gender, race, ethnicity, accent, sexual orientation, disability. Evidence on equity bias is mixed & clearest in qual comments. It’s clear equity bias, in particular, is highly conditional.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Teaching evals are weakly correlated (if at all!) with learning. SETs identify the wrong instructor as the superior teacher 37% of the time. For these reasons alone, SETs should not be used as sole indicator of teaching performance for personnel purposes. https://t.co/89f1DW5lu6

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Measurement bias occurs when variables unrelated to teaching influence SETs. Examples of course characteristics that bias evals: class time, class size, lecture format, difficulty, discipline. Examples of student characteristics: interest in material, previous coursework.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: As a result, we take a different approach. We read, and read, and categorized, and read again the many articles on SET biases. Our goal with this paper is to explain the complexity of evidence on SET biases & provide pragmatic recommendations for how to use this imperfect tool.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: 1) Quant data from sources like RMP, non-SET surveys, questions from SETs that have unique wording, 2) experimental designs, 3) qualitative, open-answer sections of SETs, where sexist, racist or homophobic comments emerge.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Before I get to details of our findings: There are some meta-analyses of SET biases. But they don't capture complexity of SET bias. In particular, meta-analyses require comparison of similar or identical variables & models across studies. 3 types of data are generally eliminated.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: SETs are a MAJOR topic on #academictwitter. We know this issue affects people on a personal & professional level. We hope our work empowers the advocacy of those pushing to eliminate SETs *and* provides practical recommendations for the continued use of SETs in a less bad way.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Major findings: There is plenty of evidence of both measurement and equity biases. As a result, it’s absolutely critical that universities and colleges carefully evaluate how these are administered, and the role they play in personnel decisions.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Our goal with this paper is to provide a careful look at the nuances of SET biases. It's not as simple or straightforward as "SETs are biased against women and POC." The dynamics of SET biases are conditional and do, in certain conditions, advantage women and POC.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Standard evaluations of teaching (SETs) are problematic bc of known measurement & equity bias. In this new pub, @jenniesweetcush & I provide a comprehensive but nuanced overview of the literature. We make recommendations on how to use SETs responsibly. https://t.co/bW5BErZeBL https://t.co/MzJH1sSgYK

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: I’m on the autism spectrum and I thrive in environments with a lot of structure. But this year all structure went out the door. I’m feeling disorganized and off kilter. Having high goals gave me purpose, direction and satisfaction when I could cross something off my list.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @BrielleHarbin @ellenmkey @prof_mirya @daveamp @ardoinpj @jenniesweetcush I would love to see more work on that directly. The problems with SETs are multifaceted and biases have some weird patterns. I’m not creative enough to know how to come up with the right questions but I’m ready to be the #1 cheerleader and reviewer for that work!

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @BrielleHarbin @ellenmkey @prof_mirya @daveamp @ardoinpj @jenniesweetcush My hot take is that institutions won’t replace them until there is a good alternative - and best alternatives may be costly and time consuming course curriculum design and peer evals. So - if we are stuck with SETs right now, imna focus my work on how to make the use less bad.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @BrielleHarbin @ellenmkey @prof_mirya @daveamp @ardoinpj @jenniesweetcush There is a TON of work in education about the forms itself - what makes for good questions. name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: @mclemoremr It’s very common in poli sci classes online to drop in on each other’s Zooms. (I’m doing another one tomorrow!) I don’t always pass those types of talks along to other scholars because honestly it feels a bit like service and I know Black scholars face a huge service burden.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @mclemoremr (I genuinely mean this in an open way. I’m trying to do my part as a white scholar to amplify marginalized voices.)

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: @mclemoremr I feel like this puts me in a bind.  I’m def not trying to be combative, but are you implying that I shouldn’t ever teach about this concept because I’m not a Black scholar who studies this? I’m trying to be an anti-racist teacher who incorporates Black scholars in what I teach.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @mclemoremr But to a broader point: if I am asked to talk about reproductive rights in a fellow poli sci class, and I want to talk about structural inequality and oppression, i feel like I should introduce people to this theory. I genuinely try to emphasize the origins of the movement.

description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Like other intersectional frameworks: reproductive justice calls us to center the experiences of marginalized people and advocate against inequality and oppression.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: I always add: shame and stigma are killing us. We don't talk enough about issues like infertility and pregnancy loss. Keeping these issues off a public agenda places additional heartbreaking burdens felt heaviest by women.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: In other words, reproductive justice is not a set of issues; it's a way of thinking and seeing the world.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: There are SO. MANY. ISSUES. that fall under the umbrella of repro justice. Reproductive justice means thinking not just about the right not to have a child (abortion, contraception), but about the barriers people face to having a child and raising them safely. https://t.co/7ubTc6tuum

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Reproductive justice values are SO simple, but achieving reproductive justice is so hard. https://t.co/74kTOA6eVR

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: There's a lot of focus on abortion & contraception. But that belies the multifaceted nature of reproductive rights as well as systemic inequalities that shape access. Existing frameworks, like repro rights, ignore the reality that for many people - there is no "choice" available. https://t.co/zVr2IWRtte

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: I've given a talk on reproductive justice 3x in the last few weeks. Across these talks, it's clear this framework is relatively unknown (despite being around since the 90s) and it's a powerful way to think reproductive freedom. Let me share the jist of it. https://t.co/2DYluFnpx9

tweet: If you study gender & pol psych,  join us. If you don't study gender & pol psych, create this community yourself. Our network started with the efforts of two (then) junior scholars @PolisciMonica and #AngieBos. You can replicate our awesomeness, and I sincerely hope you do! #VGPP

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: But most importantly - these people have genuinely become some of my best friends in the discipline. It makes me feel like I have a place here. I know other junior gender and pol psych women feel the same way. #VGPP

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Here are a few other things I love about GPP. 1) It's a group of (mostly) women with a PLAN to take over the field and discipline. 2) People are so supportive and give good tangible advice. 3) We have a summer book club! 4) We have a fb group! 5) There are writing groups! #VGPP

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: We breakout in to small groups where junior scholars get a full 45 min of discussion on a paper. We have designated note takers and discussants are responsible for checking in after the workshop to make sure the presenter has taken tangible steps to move the paper forward. #VGPP

tweet: Third, we bring attention to the need to study "concentrated disadvantage" (see some great work from @povertyscholar on this). These are areas already vulnerable with socioeconomic and racial inequalities further isolated bc of the geography of opportunity.

tweet: Second, we introduce the method of integrated two step floating catchment areas (I2SFCA), common in applied geography, to our fields of political science and public policy. It's a sophisticated approach to measuring access that accounts for driving times and population patterns.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: A lot of research has been done on access to abortion (incl by me). Far less is done on contraception. Contraception used to be non-partisan but it's contentious today. WAY more women need affordable contraception than abortion in a given year. It's important we study it.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: This paper makes several contributions to the field. First, this is the first in-depth analysis of contraceptive access to account for patterns in where people live. We find access of this federal program is not equitable, with access varying substantially across & within states.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: We find that contraception deserts (areas with inequitable access to affordable family planning) vary substantially across the U.S. We define equity of access as places where the provision of services is greatest where services are needed most. https://t.co/itBxkv1TPh

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Our project evolved from an exploratory qualitative look at Title X (the only federal program exclusively for family planning). Along with the addition of our amazing Ph.D. students @kellenakane and @TraceeMSaunders, we turned to GIS and applied geography to evaluate access.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: .@ProfCandis and I first start theorizing about contraception deserts back in 2016. We wrote this Monkey Cage piece raising awareness of the issue and calling attention to recent political attacks to limit access to affordable contraception. https://t.co/NqaHX9bfc0

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: I'm excited to share the first article out of a multi-year project. We use innovative spatial analysis to show how the inequitable implementation of policy leaves some people (disproportionately low income, POC) in contraception deserts. @ProfCandis @kellenakane @TraceeMSaunders https://t.co/AwWE5sBGXP

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: From the excerpts, you can see her legal arguments evolve over time. You see the idea of sex as a semi-suspect class emerge across several cases. You see her advocacy of equal rights. It’s hard to fathom how significant a role RBG has played in women’s rights. 3/

tweet: I wrote a law school recommendation recently for a student who wore a MAGA hat the first time we met. She told me after class that she assumed she would hate RBG’s writing and reasoning but was surprised to find she had loved it. It was among her favorite readings in class. 2/

tweet: @ACassario Sometimes it's useful to assign breakout room roles. For instance, if breakout rooms are 4-5 people: person 1 is facilitator (poses Qs), 2 is summarizer, 3 is devil's advocate, 4 connects themes, 5 note taker. This keeps them on task.

tweet: @ACassario This is a really hard job so don't be too hard on yourself. Leading discussion based recitation is hard even in the best of times. Here are a few stray thoughts. Tell students that they will be reporting back to the whole class after the breakout rooms to improve accountability.

tweet: Next, I want to highlight some of the briefs written in my politics of policy class. These are 2 page briefs, independently written, and cover a *broad range* of policy issues. You can see a directory of briefs (and the assignment prompt, etc.) here. https://t.co/FtuMaCwEWd

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: One group focused on the Pink Tax. The Pink Tax is when products targeted towards women cost more than equivalent products targeted towards men. It also includes the cost of menstrual products, which are taxed as a luxury in most states. Learn more here! https://t.co/LelJjI4txm https://t.co/aTsq60XBvq

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: This group wrote about the experiences of LGBTQ youth in public schools. LGBTQ youth face discrimination and bullying, which really impedes their wellbeing as well as their education. They offer several tangible things schools can do. https://t.co/LelJjI4txm

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: This report gets into details about insurance and health coverage for transgender people. They cover the myriad ways that trans people are poorly served by the current health system. They advocate for universal medicare coverage. https://t.co/SJK2CWNv3R https://t.co/5828br2hsD

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: This group focuses on mental health among incarcerated women. A fair amount has been written about women's health in prisons, with the most attention going to shackling during birth. This report takes a broader look at mental health in prison. https://t.co/SJK2CWNv3R https://t.co/Bdq58eDAnl

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: This group documents discrimination in medicine. The cover discrimination in medicine by gender, gender identity, etc. They talk about the tangible implications of this discrimination and end with clear policy recommendations. https://t.co/aITCU2dIaN

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: This group is a fascinating look into representation in comics. The authors had an encyclopedic knowledge of comics and analyze gender, sexual orientation, race, and disability. They also show how comics change when they go to the screen. https://t.co/UwJtoPElCs https://t.co/tDsUcNxVrB

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: This group focused on the cosmetic industry. They tackled issues relating to social norms regarding beauty, how the beauty industry is dangerously unregulated, and racism in the cosmetic industry. https://t.co/84vt4GEwt1 https://t.co/xToE7Gpaiq

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: First, I want to highlight some of the policy reports my students did in my sexuality and gender policy class. These are group written (they pick the groups and group size). Students wrote individual sections and then worked to merge them into a cohesive document.

tweet: @pcpeay 4) Stay organized! I have a huge white board. Others do this w post-its. I like to have a thick pipeline of projects so if one stalls or a coauthor flakes - no big deal. I try to have projects at all stages. I always recommend @MattLebo4's article on this. https://t.co/sTUkZFsxrz

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @pcpeay 3cont) Every year when I make my annual goals, I update my "Aspirational 5 year CV." I write down everything I've started that could be finished in the next 5 years. It's really helped me visualize my trajectory. Here is a tweet where I talk about this. 4/ https://t.co/wzoLyIcYCa

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @pcpeay 3cont) When I started my TT job, I looked at CVs of people at similar or better places to see how many pubs, grants, etc., they had on their CV. I figured that was a good metric for what I would need to get "tenure in the discipline" rather than just tenure in my department. 3/

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: @pcpeay 3) learn to make short, medium and long term goals. I make weekly goals that scale up to semester goals, that scale up to annual goals, that scale up to long term goals. 2/

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

tweet: I set a goal in 2015 to have 10-12 articles when I went for tenure. As of today I have 12! I set this goal so that as I got closer, I wouldn’t freak out & change what I thought I needed for tenure. This reinforces for me that I respond well to goal setting & it helps my anxiety.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Schedule study hall with your friends. Zoom/Skype to chat, then everyone mute and study/listen to lectures for 30 minutes, then unmute and chat more, repeat. This serves a dual purpose of staying connected with friends and peer pressure to focus on studying.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Schedule breaks in your routine. This could be breaks to go for a run or do a plank challenge, it could be to watch tiktok videos, it could be to video chat your friends. Don’t try to do all the class work at once. You will get bored and you won’t retain as much.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Set a goal to participate in online class chatter even more than you might do in class. If you disengage from the discussion, you will feel less motivated to keep up with class. Ask questions or share news stories. Everyone will be a little bored and looking for ways to engage.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Give yourself rewards. If you watch all the lectures and do all the readings for this week, what fun thing are you going to do? Maybe rent a movie online, buy new nail polish or a face mask, or order your favorite delivery.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: Set a schedule and try to develop a routine. I’ll be binge watching more Netflix, too, but try to designate working hours and days to focus on each class. Try to develop a routine for exercise, sleep, meals, online socializing.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: I’ve never been a full time online student, so this is just me making things up. One of the hardest parts about this transition is that students keep asking me questions that I just honestly don’t know. I’m answering, but I’m also just making things up!

tweet: @jenniesweetcush presents gender dynamics of (online & in person) discussion groups, with controversial & non-controversial topics. Men & women behaved differently across contexts (i.e., more agreement in person). Also, men online more disagreeable w/ noncontroversial topics.🤣

tweet: @newlypaul @DrouinTweets I presented research with @JohnCluverius using a survey experiment about abortion policy. tweet: @SNBonaccorsi @adam_shniderman @mpfix1 I also think we should just contextualize student feedback more. SETs are lower for people who teach large classes, classses with math, required classes, etc. (In addition to biases by gender, race, LGBTQ). It isn't fair to use SETs for hiring and promotion given those concerns.

name: Dr. Rebecca Kreitzer
description: policy/polisci @unc studying inequality, representation, repro health, pol feedback & state politics. MN for life; now #ncpol. she/her #ActuallyAutistic 🏳️‍🌈
tweet: @SNBonaccorsi @adam_shniderman @mpfix1 I agree. I don't think we should eliminate student feedback entirely. I think we should be more careful about how it is solicited, including the phrasing of question prompts, because the question wording is associated with bias for certain people.
